title: Big Ride: Monte Zoncolan – steeped in history
content:
Cyclist
Big Ride: Monte Zoncolan – steeped in history

Google ‘Europe’s hardest cycling climb’ and Monte Zoncolan is bound to show up within the first handful of search results. It’s quite the billing to have, and for any cyclist it’s hard to ignore the challenge of ticking off the much-heralded ‘toughest climb of the Giro d’Italia’, which is why I find myself in the town of Ovaro in Italy’s northeast, layering up under overcast skies and scanning the hillsides for any clues about what is to come.

In preparation, I dug deep on the internet for testimonials from fellow cyclists. I wish I hadn’t. What I encountered were tales of pain and hardship that would rival a Dickens novel, backed up by statistics telling of sustained average gradients of over 12% for more than 10km, with some sections spiking above 20%. The Zoncolan’s numbers are alien to the average cafe ride or Sunday spin, and as we set off I can’t help but feel there are some occasions when it’s better to live in ignorance.

The gates of hell

Following the flow of the Degano River, Scott – my ride companion for the day – and I warm up our legs with a brief roll into town, knowing well that there is very little preamble before hitting the test we’re almost too nervous to acknowledge. In fact, no sooner have we turned off the main road through town than we pass under a wooden arch stretching across the road like an archer’s bow to indicate that we are now at the start of the climb.

Despite its folkloric status in the sport, the Zoncolan is a relatively recent discovery for the Giro d’Italia. The women’s race was first to tackle this Carnic Alp in 1997, with Italian Fabiana Luperini taking the stage win on her way to the overall title. Six years later the men tackled its slopes for the first time and Gilberto Simoni claimed the stage en route to the maglia rosa in 2003. On these initial runs, however, the organisers settled on the eastern approach from Sutrio before switching to the tougher western ascent from Ovaro in 2007 (also won by Simoni).

Since then, the Giro has alternated between the two routes for five further visits to the men’s and women’s races, most recently from Sutrio in 2021 when Lorenzo Fortunato held on from the morning breakaway to take the win over the summit on his Giro debut. The last time the Giro raced up the Zoncolan from the Ovaro side was in 2018 when both the men’s and women’s events tackled the climb, with Chris Froome and Annemiek van Vleuten winning both the stage and the overall.

Related Posts

Big Ride: The secret road up Monte Zoncolan

Big Ride: Borderline crazy in the Carnic Alps

Classic climb: Monte Zoncolan, a savage Italian climb so steep it makes the pros look slow

When Froome arrived at the Zoncolan that day, he already had 175km of riding in his legs. For me the number is nearer 2.5km, but despite that – or perhaps because of it – the slopes are already starting to bite. The Beata Vergine del Carmine Church displays the steepness of the road by requiring sturdy concrete stilts to stop it tumbling down the hillside.

Just a kilometre up the road lies the village of Liariis, where the locals have been known to cheekily drape a banner above the road emblazoned with the words ‘La Porta per l’Inferno’, or ‘the gates of hell’ to you and I. Over breakfast I was warned that the fountain in Liariis is where the real climbing begins, so when I see it slip by I know what to expect and I’m not thrilled at the prospect.

Clicking into a smaller gear, I’m greeted by the first rider in the Zoncolan’s hall of fame on a sign to my left: Ottavio Bottecchia, the first Italian to win the Tour de France. In his day the Giro didn’t dare come up here. At approximately every half-kilometre into the climb, a signpost presents another picture of a Giro hero to spur you on or mock your efforts, depending on your point of view. Bottecchia is followed by the likes of Alfredo Binda, Louison Bobet and Charly Gaul. Further up you’ll find Eddy Merckx, Bernard Hinault, Miguel Induráin and, of course, Marco Pantani.

As we move deeper through the Giro history books, the road curls through the first of its 22 hairpins – that’s one more than the Tour de France’s Alpe d’Huez, if you’re counting. To mark the occasion, the Crocce della Ciclista, a crucifix sculpted from bike forks and a handlebar, pokes out from the roadside in sparkling form. There’s a penance to be paid if you stop to read the plaque below, however. At 22% gradient it’ll take more than a couple of Hail Marys to get your feet clipped in again.

The daily grind

For much of the climb the road is enclosed by woodland, making it hard to get any sense of progress. Only the occasional gap in the trees, revealing views out over the Carnian Valley, assures us that we’re gaining height, while the signposts – hello Francesco, hello Giuseppe, hello Gianni – serve to slowly tick off the kilometres.

As we get higher, the signposts become more faded and difficult to read. Or that might just be the sweat in my eyes. With no bike computer I can’t tell how slowly I’m going but it’s certainly in single figures, and the distance of the climb is getting longer all the time owing to the necessity to zigzag across the road just to stay upright.

With legs screaming, the flamme rouge announcing the Zoncolan’s final kilometre is a welcome sight, indicated by the scribblings of ultimo km sprayed on the adjacent rockface. We pass through a series of dark tunnels where the sound of trickling water reverberates, and when we emerge into the sunlight we can see the four remaining hairpins stacked almost on top of one another to our right.

In short succession we pass by Gino Bartali, Fausto Coppi and Gilberto Simoni. As I press on the pedals I try to imagine the cauldron of noise here on race day, and it’s not until the final turn that I realise we have arrived at the top to be welcomed by Annemiek van Vleuten.

While I can’t match her sense of victory on crossing the line, I’m pretty certain I can match her sense of relief.

More punishment to come

Once over the summit, the road drops as precipitously as it rose, touching -25% at its most devilish. Instead of following the strade provinciale, we turn off to the right and take a more scenic route down. This isn’t the way the Giro d’Italia usually comes, and I can see why. The tarmac is broken in places and the occasional cambered corner catches us off guard. Through the bends, framed images of Jesus decorated with faux flowers hang from the wall separating us from the lush Friulian creeks, echoing with the sound of white water.

I can finally return to the hoods once we’re spat out past a worn-down chapel and shackled up tabaccheria in Priola, before pink ribbons tied across road signs welcome us to Sutrio, the larger of the two Zoncolan base camps.

A supermarket lunch later, we clip back in and follow the Bût river upstream. There’s little time to settle in, however, as before long the road starts to tilt upwards again towards the hillside village of Cercivento, once buried by mudslides in the 17th century.

Turning westwards, there’s a considerable uptick in the amount of graffiti. This isn’t the work of any old village delinquents, but rather Slovenian fans who etched the names of Domen Novak and Tadej Pogačar to mark the Giro’s arrival last May. One supporter even spray-painted ‘Pogi’ over a traffic mirror. Naughty, naughty.

From here, the incline persists to the base of the second major obstacle of the day, Monte Crostis. It’s a climb less familiar to the likes of Pogačar, having never been included in the Giro, though not for want of trying. It was due to be included in 2011 but was ruled out the night before its scheduled inclusion due to safety concerns.

As it is, we’re tackling it in reverse, opting for the southeastern ascent from Ravascletto. This is supposedly ‘the easier side’, but the meat of the climb still lasts 10km at an average of 9.3%, which is steeper than your average hors catégorie climb at the Tour de France even if it feels like a relief after the outrageous numbers of the Zoncolan.

Worn-down refuges and farmhouses hang off the slopes while the road snakes around some lazy hairpins. As we break through the tree line, a glance to the right sees the road cut into the forested slopes below, tying up the obscured view like a ribbon. Now at 1,600m altitude we are well and truly in the clouds, with mist reducing visibility to barely 20 metres in front of us. Views into the valley are now a thing of the past, and then the road changes surface without warning. From now on, asphalt is out and gravel is in.

It’s not every day that you get to skip across gravel atop an Alp coated in a dream-like mist. I’m assured that the vistas would be unbeatable atop this panoramic road if it weren’t for the low-lying cloud, but I’m unbothered. The surprises that reveal themselves through each misty bend keep me on my ever-cooling toes. A shrine, puddle, waterfall or dip in the road – it all feels so surreal.

After around 6km on the sterrato, the surface returns to asphalt in time for a momentary 10% kicker to the summit of Monte Crostis, its sticker-coated sign standing ominously in the fog. We don’t hang around – a quick descent brings us back below the cloud line to once again reveal the Alpine views that our recent altitude has been denying us.

In the town of Tualis we pass through the Piazza Giro d’Italia, a name that is perhaps wishful thinking given the Giro has steered clear of the Monte Crostis since the 2011 debacle. Still, it’s not often you see street names dedicated to bike races. And it’s only a couple more kilometres before we rejoin the road alongside the Degano River that will take us the last few clicks back to Ovaro.

Freewheeling with the wind at our backs, suddenly the fearsome Monte Zoncolan doesn’t seem so scary after all.

Monte Zoncolan

Europe’s toughest climb – or so they say

Monte Zoncolan is negotiable from two sides: Ovaro and Sutrio. The 9% average Sutrio route was used for the Zoncolan’s Giro christening in 1997 for the women’s race, on a stage won by Italian Fabiana Luperini. The men first sampled the Sutrio side in 2003, when eventual Giro champion Gilberto Simoni took stage honours. 

The headline-grabbing Ovaro side, with its average gradient of 12.3%, debuted in 2005, with Simoni again taking stage glory. Since then, the Ovaro side has garnered the title of the most vicious climb that Italy – and perhaps Europe – can offer.

In recent history, Michael Rogers beat Francesco Manuel Bongiorno on the Zoncolan in 2014 after the latter was forced to unclip on the 20% slopes due to fan encroachment. Later, Chris Froome claimed his first Giro stage on the Zoncolan in 2018, beginning a surprise turnaround in the GC.

How we did it

Travel 

Direct flights to Venice-Marco Polo Airport are regularly scheduled from London, Birmingham, Manchester, Edinburgh and Bristol. From Venice, it’s roughly a two-hour drive (190km) to Ovaro. Treviso and Trieste airports are also within a two-hour journey from Ovaro, with frequent direct flights there from London.

Accommodation  

Cyclist stayed at Hotel Aplis (hotelaplisovaro.it) in Ovaro, which is ideal for cyclists as it has a dedicated garage for bikes and a Zoncolan merchandise shop. Located beside the Degano River, downtown Ovaro and the foot of the Monte Zoncolan are just a short walk or ride away. Rooms start from €55 per night.

Thanks  

Many thanks to Silvio from Visit Zoncolan (visitzoncolan.com) and Pro Loco Sutrio (prolocosutrio.com) who guided us around the route and supported us on the ride.

Thanks also to the team at Pro Loco Ovaro (prolocoovaro.wixsite.com) for organising our accommodation at Hotel Aplis.

author: Mdonlevy
